moves.1. d4: In this game, after a level opening, I drop a pawn to a pretty combination. I fight on and manage to reach a level ending. I reach a position where they is just one move to draw. Unfortunately I don't find it, and I lose!
moves.1... Nf6: So this was playing in round 6 of the 4NCL (National Chess League), Division 3, North.
moves.2... e6: Likely to lead to the Queen's Indian Defence after Nf3 or the Nimzo Indian after Nc3.
moves.3... Bb4: Which he plays, although he could have transposed into a Queen's Gambit with d5 or a Benoni with c5.
moves.5... d5: I'm very happy after this move, as now, if ever he doubles my c pawns with Bxc3, I can always undouble them.
moves.7. a3: I now think 0-0 is more accurate, and will play 0-0 if I have this position again.
moves.8... Qc7: With a threat of taking on d4 and then on c4 and I can't recapture with the bishop.
moves.9. cxd5: To meet that threat I make an exchange which I don't really want to make. I found out later that Qc2 is the usual move in this position.
moves.10... c4: And he closes down the position for his two knights. In doing so he takes us out of the Gameknot opening databases (not that we were using them at the time of course!
moves.12... Re8: He picks the wrong way to stop it, as this doesn't actually stop it. Bf5 was better,
moves.13. e4: Now, if he plays Nxe4 14. Nxe4 Rxe4 15.	Bf3 regains the pawn. But I couldn't have played this, if he had played Bf5! last move.
moves.13... dxe4: So he takes this way instead.
moves.16. Ne3: I carry on with my plan.
moves.17. Bb2: I develop. This move is a mistake. What should I have played instead, and why?
moves.21. Rab1: Played partly with the idea of retreating the bishop to a1.
moves.22. Rfd1: So that the rook is not attacked when the knight comes in to d3.
moves.22... Ba4: Perhaps he should have played this last move?
moves.27. Bc1: I decide that on a1, I am vulnerable to a later e4-e3 thrust.
moves.31. Kf1: I continue to bring my king up.
moves.31... Rd7: What is this? Is he really wanting to exchange my weak isolated d pawn for his b pawn?
moves.35... g5: He tries to mobilize his king side majority.
moves.36... Ra5: He wants to be able to play Kf6-e5.
moves.41. Rc3: I am sure this is a drawn position now.
moves.45. Ra4: So I hit his a pawn.
moves.45... Rc7 46. Kf3 Rb7 47. Ra5: The only way he can make progress is to sacrifice his a pawn.
moves.47... Rb3+ 48. Kf2 Kg4 49. Rxa7: We now reach an ending with a total of 6 pieces, so after the game I was able to analyse this using a free  on-line chess ending database. As I suspected, it is drawn, but it is hard to draw!
Ok. This is the position, where there is only one move for white to draw. Without cheating and looking at your own database, find it!
moves.55. Ra7: Did you find it? The move I should have played is Rf7+ which draws. (suggest you do set it up on a database and check!) I am now lost.
moves.55... f2 56. Rf7+ Kg3 57. Ke3 Kg2 58. Rg: The rook, and the game is lost, but it was a lost position anyway. Many thanks for reading, please rate this annotation on the star system, and leave a comment or two! Until next time, dear reader!
